tr:secmain.core:title: Administrative Relief.
tr:secmain.core:para: In the event of a successful administrative review, the remedy can vary according to the individual case. Where procedural defects are found, the administrative decision can be vacated and remanded for further consideration upon the application of proper procedures. Where the claim addresses a substantive right, the court may reverse the decision of the administrative agency and order the agency to provide the relief originally requested—such as issuing a zoning permit or certificate of occupancy.

Where a statute awards attorney’s fees to a prevailing party, a party bringing any case that succeeds in invalidating any administrative rule for any reason is entitled to all of that party’s reasonable litigation expenses, including attorney’s fees, even if the ultimate relief requested—the rescinding of a permit—is denied.
Citizens Organizing Project v. Department of Natural Resources, 189 Ill. 2d 593, 598–599, 727 N.E.2d 195, 198 (2000) (objecting citizen’s group only convinced court that the standard of review should be the “preponderance of the evidence,” instead of “clear and convincing evidence,” but was entitled under 5ILCSS 100/10-55(c) to its attorney’s fees).

tr:secmain.core:title: Injunctive Relief.
tr:secmain.core:para:
Equitable relief is not available to enjoin an alleged taking of property for a public use.
Ruckelshaussss v. Monsanto Co., 467 U.S. 986, 1016, 104 S. Ct. 2862, 2880, 81 L. Ed. 2d 815 (1984). However, an injunction may be issued where the government enters into property without first exercising its right of eminent domain.
See e.g. Pardildddla v. Village of Hoffman Estates, 2023 IL App (1st) 211580, 235 N.E.3d 1186.

Despite the often-repeated admoniqqqtion that Illinois courts do not sit as “super zoning agencies,” the presumption of validity of the local zoning ordinance, and the deference accorded the trial court on appeal, statistical studies suggest that Illinois courts have been quite active in overturning zoning determinations on constitutional grounds. A 1979 study of 54 zoning amendment cases in Illinois found that the local government’s zoning decision was reversed in 63% of the cases. Some balance was struck on appeal; the appellate court in turn reversed the trial court in 39% of the cases, but the appellate court still reversed the zoning authority in 52% of the cases. Only in 20% of the cases did both the trial and appellate courts uphold the local zoning decision.
Charles Haar, Et al., Quantitatrrrive Analysis of Zoning Amendment Litigation: Computer Power and Legal Reasoning (Report to the National Science Foundation 1979). It is thus apparent that judicial relief can be a viable alternative for the developer or property owner stymied at the level of local government approvals.

The ultimate legal determination in judicial review of zoning is a declaration as to the reasonableness of the existing land use restrictions, and an injunction barring the enforcement of the existing zoning. If this were the only relief granted, it would leave the property, for all intents and purposesunzonedddd.”
NorwoodoBldrsrsrsrsrsrs. vCitoDesePlaineseseses, 128 Ill. App. 3d 908, 918, 471 N.E.2d 634, 640 (1st Dist. 1984); Reeve vVillagoGlenviewewewew, 29 Ill. 2d 611, 616, 195 N.E.2d 188, 191 (1963); see, e.g., Mangel CovWilmettetetete, 115 Ill. App. 2d 383, 253 N.E.2d 9, 14–16 (1st Dist. 1969) (underlying zoning held void, but proposed use found unreasonable; propertwaleftunzonedededed” as a result of litigation, but when settlement failed, village subsequently adopted a wholly new zoning classification). At least two undesirable consequences flow from such a result. First, it may trigger a second round of litigation if, upon municipal rezoning, a new category equally unacceptable to the owner is selected by the municipality.
Sinclair Pipe Line Co. VillaRichtontontonton Park, 19 Ill. 2d 370, 167 N.E.2d 406, 411 (1960), and cases cited therein. Alternatively, if an owner won an injunction barring the existing zoning based in part on a favorable proposed use, the owner might then be able to implement a different and unrelated use on the property.
Id.

To avoid these possibilities, the courts require that relief in typical zoning litigation be crafted with reference to a specific proposed use, as reflected in the record of the proceedings before the court.
Id.﻿Geft Outdoo4, LLC v. City of Evansville, 110 F.4th 935, 938 (7th Cir. 2024)\. A zoning ordinance may be set aside only to the extent necessary to permit the specific use proposed by the owner.
Texaco, Inc. VillaSchaumburgurgurgurg, 135 Ill. App. 3d 1084, 1086, 482 N.E.2d 657, 659 (1st Dist. 1985); Schultz v. Village of Lisle, 53 Ill. 2d 39, 289 N.E.2d 614, 616 (1972). This makes the practice in a declaratory judgment and injunction action similar to that in administrative review of the denial of a zoning variation and to that where a mandamus is requested for a building permit to issue.
Sinclair Pipe Line Co. VillaRichtontontonton Park, 19 Ill. 2d 370, 167 N.E.2d 406, 411 (1960). The purpose of this rule is to bind both the landowner and the municipality to the adjudication of one specific use, as well as to prevent multiplicity of litigation.
Texacoooo, Inc. VillaSchaumburgurgurgurg, 135 Ill. App. 3d 1084, 1086, 482 N.E.2d 657, 659 (1st Dist. 1985).

The degree of specificity required in the decree varies. The specific use must be introduced into evidence, and the decree must be framed with reference to the specific plan proposed.
Texaco, Inc. VillaSchaumburgurgurgurg, 135 Ill. App. 3d 1084, 1086, 482 N.E.2d 657, 659 (1st Dist. 1985); Robrock CounPiattattattatt, 2012 IL App (4th) 110590, ¶ 66, 967 N.E.2d 822, 831 (injunction barring use of any portion of tproperasgyrocopterterterter air field was reversed and held applicable only to the 79.5 acres that had been the subject of the special use permit at issue). (May 29, 2025 sl. op. at 12-13) (so much delay “that the process sometimes seems to ‘borde[r] on the Kafkaesque’ ”)\. When the evidence in one case explored in detail the particulars of a specific site plan proposal, the court correctly enjoined enforcement of the zoning ordinance only to the extent necessary to permit the specific use that the plaintiffs proposed.
Nelson v. City of Rockford, 19 Ill. 2d 410, 167 N.E.2d 219, 221 (1960). In a similar case, an order was affirmed which enjoined enforcement of the ordinance if the property were developed “substantially” in accordance with the testimony at trial.
Illinois Nat’l Bank & Trust Co. v. County of Winnebago, 19 Ill. 2d 487, 167 N.E.2d 401, 406 (1960) When the evidence that was offered concerned the compatibility of commercial and light industrial uses with uses on the surrounding property, the court’s decree invalidating the existing residential zoning, as well as any other classification other than commercial or light industrial, was affirmed.
Franklin v. Village of Franklin Park, 19 Ill. 2d 381, 167 N.E.2d 195, 196–97 (1960). However, a decree allowing any use under a particular zoning classification, not in accordance with a specific plan, is too broad.
Seilerlerlerlerlerlerler v. City of Granite City, 255 Ill. App. 3d 210, 213, 625 N.E.2d 1170, 1172 (5th Dist. 1993); Smeja v. County of Boone, 34 Ill. App. 3d 628, 632, 339 N.E.2d 452, 456 (2d Dist. 1975); Fiore v. City of Highland Park, 76 Ill. App. 2d 62, 221 N.E.2d 323, 330 (2d Dist. 1966). The trial court has no authority to impose its own zoning classification on the property.
Littlejohnohnohnohnohnohnohn v. City of N. Chicago, 259 Ill. App. 3d 713, 631 N.E.2d 358, 367 (2d Dist. 1994) (trial court reversed when ordering property rezoned to “R-1, or any classification under which church services are allowed as a special use”).

To allow the court to craft its decree, not every detail of the proposed use must be placed in evidence, but at least enough of the general characteristics that bear on the reasonableness of the zoning classification must be introduced.
Sinclair Pipe Line Co. VillaRichtontontonton Park, 19 Ill. 2d 370, 167 N.E.2d 406, 411 (1960). The decree is specific to the property, and to the proposed use, but not to the plaintiffs; who may make use of the property in the manner approved is not material.
Bass CiJolietietietiet, 10 Ill. App. 3d 860, 295 N.E.2d 53, 63 (3d Dist. 1973).

While the use must be specified, and is normally specified by the introduction of a site plan, a site plan is not strictly necessary. So long as there is sufficient specificity detailing the nature of the use, a specific plan is not required. Thus, where there was extensive testimony of the types of uses proposed, photographs of buildings comparable to what would be built, and reference to some of the bulk regulations from the city’s zoning ordinance which would be observed, this was enough to allow the trial court to adequately frame a decree.
NorwoBldrsdrs. v. CiDesDPlainesnesnes, 128 Ill. App. 3d 908, 921, 471 N.E.2d 634, 642 (1st Dist. 1984).

When an amendment to a zoning ordinance is challenged, a different rule applies. If the court finds the new zoning valid, the property remains zoned in accordance with the amendment. If the court finds the new zoning invalid, the property reverts to its prior zoning. There is thus no reason for the court to craft a decree with respect to a particular use, and no authority for a court to impose conditions on development different from those in the original municipal ordinance.
Treadway v. City of Rockford, 24 Ill. 2d 488, 492, 182 N.E.2d 219, 222 (1962); Oak Park Nat’l Bank v. City of Chicago, 10 Ill. App. 3d 258, 294 N.E.2d 42, 51 (1st Dist. 1973).

Where a specific plan is proposed, the court need not go beyond a declaration of the invalidity of the zoning as applied to the subject property, plus an injunction against continued enforcement of the existing ordinance as it relates to that proposed use. It is not necessary to order the municipality to issue building permits,
Illinois Nat’l Bank & Trust Co. v. County of Winnebago, 19 Ill. 2d 487, 167 N.E.2d 401, 406 (1960); Nelson v. City of Rockford, 19 Ill. 2d 410, 167 N.E.2d 219, 221 (1960). or to enjoin the owners from using the property for uses permitted under the invalid zoning.
Nelson v. City of Rockford, 19 Ill. 2d 410, 167 N.E.2d 219, 221 (1960).

Although trial judges must have the wisdom of Solomon, some of his methods are not available in a LaSalle case. Thus, a court may not grant only a portion of the relief requested, approving part of a proposed use, but not all.
Texaco, Inc.VillageSchaumburgburgburg, 135 Ill. App. 3d 1084, 1087, 482 N.E.2d 657, 660 (1st Dist. 1985) (court could not approve gasoline station and mini-mart but reject car wash which was part of the single, integrated site plan); NorwBldrsldrs.CityDesyPlainesinesines, 128 Ill. App. 3d 908, 928, 471 N.E.2d 634, 647 (1st Dist. 1984) (reversing trial court which found single-family zoning invalid and approved commercial aspect of proposal but not multi-family and industrial aspects); Exchange Nat’l BankCityWaukeganeganegan, 85 Ill. App. 2d 461, 229 N.E.2d 562, 565 (2d Dist. 1967) (reversing trial court which affirmed single-family zoning on western portion of parcel but enjoined it on eastern portion, allowing the apartments proposed only on the eastern portion); but see Pettee v. County of DeKalb, 60 Ill. App. 3d 304, 376 N.E.2d 720, 726 (2d Dist. 1978) (proposed use of residential and aircraft landing uses allowed but commercial component found unreasonable and held barred by existing agricultural zoning restrictions). There are several reasons why the courts are so constrained. First, to allow the court to pick and choose among elements of the proposed use would give the court, not the legislative authorities, final responsibility for the minute details of zoning. Second, approving only a portion of the proposal would violate the Bright doctrine, because the trial judge would select a partial proposal the municipal authorities were never asked to approve.
Exchange Nat’l BankCityWaukeganeganegan, 85 Ill. App. 2d 461, 229 N.E.2d 562, 565 (2d Dist. 1967).

Just as the challenger must present a proposal complete in use, so too must the challenger present a proposal complete in time. When the challenger presented only an interim use (albeit an extremely significant interim use) and asked that the court change the zoning from residential to industrial to allow some unspecified use aflandfillinglingling operations were complete, the court could not engage in such judicial rezoning.
Cosmopolitan Nat’l Bank v. County of Cook, 103 Ill. 2d 302, 469 N.E.2d 183, 194 (1984).

Typically, the decree orders the municipality or county to process the proposal according to the normal operation of all ordinances other than the zoning ordinance, which is considered inapplicable only to the extent necessary to permit the specific use that is proposed.
Anundson v. City of Chicago, 44 Ill. 2d 491, 256 N.E.2d 1, 5 (1970). Thus, the proposal must still comply with licensing, building code and other such requirements.
TewsWoolhiseriser, 352 Ill. 212, 223, 185 N.E. 827 (1933) (decree should address zoning issues, but permit for underground tanks at a gas station was an unrelated matter); Duyneuyne v. City of Crest Hill, 136 Ill. App. 3d 920, 926, 483 N.E.2d 1307, 1310 (3d Dist. 1985). Where the proposal would still violate some requirements, the injunctive relief can be conditioned upon correcting specific violations.
Oak Forest Mobile Home Park, Inc. v. City of Oak Forest, 27 Ill. App. 3d 303, 326 N.E.2d 473, 489 (1st Dist. 1975). The court does not have the authority to impose specific additional conditions on a proposed use.
KambichVillageRiverwoodsoodsoods, 308 Ill. App. 3d 772, 779, 721 N.E.2d 709, 715 (2d Dist. 1999) (no authority to modify cap on school enrollment). While a decree may require compliance with the general laws of the municipality, the court must stop there and may not select specific elements of restriction to be imposed on the proposed use.
Swim Club of Rockford, Ltd. v. City of Rockford, 130 Ill. App. 3d 353, 360–361, 473 N.E.2d 1375, 1381 (2d Dist. 1985) (rejection of special use to allow liquor sales at swim club overturned; court was without authority to restrict sales to club members and to specific time periods).

Litigation can be protracted, and time may be on the side of those challenging the validity of the ordinance. While an owner can proceed with development pursuant to validly granted zoning while the litigation is pending, doing so may be at the owner’s peril. When an owner builds in the face of a suit seeking an injunction against the use, the courts uniformly have said that the owner may be required to demolish the use if the grant of zoning is later found to be invalid. While few courts ever actually do order demolition, it does sometime happen.
See GreerIllinHousHoDevDevvDevv. Auth., 122 Ill. 2d 462, 517, 524 N.E.2d 561, 586 (1988) (“We acknowledge that the grant of equitable relief may depend in part upon the changed circumstance that the project has now actually been built.”). For example, a Florida court overturned a local commission’s interpretation of its master plan, and found a 40-unit, five-building apartment complex to be in excess of density restrictions. The court enforced the statutory remedy of injunction, and ordered the buildings demolished, at a cost to the developer of $3.3 million, even though the diminution in value of the plaintiff’s home was only $26,000, and the diminution in value of all neighbors’ property was just under $300,000; the order was upheld on appeal.
Pinecrest Lakes, Shidelidelidel, 795 So.2d 191 (Fla.App. 4th Dist. 2001).

Closer to home, an Illinois court focused on the issue of intent in determining whether demolition would be required in the case of building code violations. If there was no intentional violationbuildingunpermittedttedtted structure, then the trial court should balance the equities, including the cost of removal and the diminution in value of the owner’s property against the harm the public would suffer if the structure remained. However, if the violation was intentional, the trial court could (but did not have to) order demolition without balancing the equities.
County of Kendallv. Rosenwinkel, 353 Ill. App. 3d 529, 539–540, 818 N.E.2d 425, 435 (2d Dist. 2004). Although there was no further review in that case, the Illinois Supreme Court later overruled the decision in a different case, holding that there can be no balancing of the equities when the underlying ordinance calls for injunctive relief.
City of Rock Falls v. Aims Industrial Servs., LLC, 2024 IL 129164, ¶¶ 21, 25, ___ ___ ___ ___ (when a statute authorizes an injunction, the balance of equities “is reflected in the policy choices contained within the statute. A court is not free to disregard or ‘rebalance’ the policy”). A high school district built new bleachers at its football field without a permit, arguing that it was exempt from local zoning, but the bleachers were ordered torn down when neighbors filed suit. The decision was affirmed on appeal, although the issue of injunctive relief was not addressed by the Illinois Supreme Court.
Gurba v. Community High School Dist. No. 155, 2015 IL 118332, 40 N.E.3d 1.

Owners and developers are understandably reluctant to risk the substantial investment of proceeding until the litigation is resolved.
See Equity AsInNorthbrookhbrookhbrook, 171 Ill. App. 3d 115, 124, 524 N.E.2d 1119, 1126 (1st Dist. 1988) (hardship to owner was in deciding not to proceed with construction in face of challenge to zoning approval, but that did not constittakGulickGulickGulick v. Hamilton, 287 Ill. 367, 374, 122 N.E. 537 (1919) (when suit filed to enjoin obstruction of alleged alley, there was no preliminary injunction requested and defendant completed his construction, but upon judgment he was ordered to remove the obstruction and demolish his construction). A case is not mooted simply because the development is completed before a final judgment is rendered. Where property is conveyed in the face of a lis pendens notice, the new purchasers take subject to the results of the litigation.
O’Laughlin v. City of Chicago, 65 Ill. 2d 183, 192, 357 N.E.2d 472, 477 (1976) (despite denial by circuit court and appellate court of city’s request for stay, when judgment in favor of owner reversed and owner ordered to correct the zoning violation, subsequent purchasers of property were bound by judgment). A different rule may apply where there is no lis pendens and the grantees are true third parties, unretgrantorrantorrantor-party.
See Pinnacle Corp. v. Village of Lake in the Hills, 258 Ill. App. 3d 205, 208, 630 N.E.2d 502, 505 (2d Dist. 1994) (case not mooted by transfer of lots to third parties where record does not demonstrate that they were unrelated to plaintiff). A case is mooted when the proposed development is rendered impossible, as where a portion of the property is condemned.
Hazdra Homes, Inc. v. County of Du Page, 27 Ill. App. 3d 685, 326 N.E.2d 561, 566 (2d Dist. 1975).

The leverage of time is not completely on the side of those challenging a proposed use. When the grant of zoning approval includes a time limitation in which development must commence, but litigation intervenes, the court has both jurisdiction and equitable authority to toll the running of the time period contained in the ordinance.
Homeowners Organized to Protect the Env’t, Inc. v. FirsBarringtonrringtonrrington, 167 Ill. App. 3d 714, 724, 521 N.E.2d 1202, 1209 (2d Dist. 1988). However, an order tolling the time period must be specifically requested; tolling is not automatic.
Kaminv. Kamin, 170 Ill. App. 3d 312, 315, 524 N.E.2d 625, 627 (2d Dist. 1988) (appeal dismissed as moot when time period in which to obtain building permit under variance expired and no stay had been requested); VilWilmetteWilmetteWilmette, 148 Ill. App. 3d 108, 116–17, 498 N.E.2d 712, 718 (2d Dist. 1986) (limitations period not applied when defendants did not undertake construction only because of plaintiff’s litigation challenging the grant of the special use).

Permanent injunctive relief from the violation of an existing zoning ordinance is available if the plaintiff (1) has a clear and ascertainable right in need of protection, (2) will suffer irreparable harm if the injunction does not issue, and (3) there exists no adequate remedy at law.
FredeGaca v. Gaca, 2020 IL App (3d) 200154, ¶ 35, 179 N.E.3d 917, 928.

The differences between a temporary restraining order, a preliminary injunction and a permanent injunction were featured in a case involving operating hours restrictions on a quarry. The lower court granted a temporary restraining order barring operations after hours, but the order limaTROeaTROeRTROTROA TROTROA TRO without notice may by extendonlyTROsyTROsROsyTROs TROs.
ILCS ILCS 5/11-101. A TRO with notice but without a hearing may only extend for a “short time” after the ten-day limit, so as to prevent the potential significant consequences of only a summary proceeding to exist more than a short period oTROTROa
CoBPlotev BPlotev. Plote Construction, Inc., 2017 IL App (2d) 160184, ¶ 27, 77 N.E.3d 671, 677–678. TROTROa TRO is issued with both notice and a hearing, it is the functional equivalent of a preliminary injunction, and lacks any necessary definite duration.
CoBPlotev BPlotev. Plote Construction, Inc., 2017 IL App (2d) 160184, ¶ 28, 77 N.E.3d 671, 678. The order entered in the case was thus found to be still valid seven months later, and the defendant in contempt for violating it.

When a preliminary injunction is granted barring development pending completion of a lawsuit, the necessary bond can be an onerous requirement. A 2003 case held that it was error to fail to take into account a plaintiff’s status as a not-for-profit organization with limited assets in assessing what should be the amount of the bond.
Save the Prairie Society v. Greene Development Group, Inc., 338 Ill. App. 3d 800, 805–806, 789 N.E.2d 389, 394 (1st Dist. 2003). This would apparently mean that the bond requirement can be waived altogether when the plaintiff has few resources and the injunction would be in the public interest. However, a well-respected federal jurist firmly rejected that approach,
Habitat Education Center v. United States Forest Service, 607 F.3d 453, 459–60 (7th Cir. 2010). and another Illinois court strictly enforced both the bond requirement and the ability of the defendant to recover costs and damages from a preliminary injunction improperly granted.
RoBuckhartBuckhart Action Group v. Young, 394 Ill. App. 3d 773, 780, 914 N.E.2d 1251, 1258 (4th Dist. 2009) (“Defendant was engaged in a lawful business and the expansion of his hog farm was put on hold at plaintiff’s behest. A party should not be able to throw up a legal roadblock in the path of another’s business without the adversely affected party having the opportunity to seek financial recourse if it is found to have been wrongfully impacted. To do otherwise would indeed invite spurious, vindictive, or spiteful litigation.”).

tr:secmain.core:title: Damages.
tr:secmain.core:para: Damages are not usually awarded in land use cases unless the court determines that a taking has occurred. The declaratory and injunctive relief in a LaSalle case is usually considered adequate relief by the court, and no damages are awarded in addition thereto.

However, in some cases damages may be an alternative to injunctive relief. Injunctive relief is generally appropriate when there is intentional encroachment on adjoining property.
JCRE Holdings, LLC v. GLK Land Trust, 2019 IL App (3d) 180677, ¶ 21, 136 N.E.3d 202, 206. But where the encroachment is unintentional, the cost of removing the encroachment is great, the corresponding benefit to the adjoining landowner is small, and damages can be had at law, the courts will ordinarily refuse to grant the injunction and award damages instead.
JCRE Holdings, LLC v. GLK Land Trust, 2019 IL App (3d) 180677, ¶ 22, 136 N.E.3d 202, 206 (where roof overhang built with permission, but successor landowner withdrew permission, injunction reversed in favor of damages). Likewise, when a retaining wall was improperly erected in a utility easement, the decrease in value of the adjoining property was the basis for an award of damages, but not an injunction.
Oak Run Property Owners Assoc., Inc. v. Basta, 2019 IL App (3d) 180687, ¶ 73, 145 N.E.3d 513, 526.

tr:secsub1.core:title: In General.
tr:secsub1.core:para:
The rights of private parties to receive the award in an eminent domain proceeding are correlative—the rights of one depend on the rights of the other. When the condemnor acquires a vested right in the property, the owner has a vested right in the compensation.
City of Chicago v. Barbian, 80 Ill. 482, 485–86 (1875). But the proceeding is not over when the title is vested in the condemnor and the money has been deposited with the county treasurer. Still to be determined is the ultimate question of who gets the money. Under the Eminent Domain Act, the court has the exclusive authority to determine all rights to the award of just compensation.
735 ILCS 30/10-5-70; Village of Palatine v. Palatine Assocs., LLC, 2012 IL App (1st) 102707, ¶ 49, 966 N.E.2d 1174, 1188.

tr:secsub1.core:title: Rights to the Award of Just Compensation.
tr:secsub1.core:para:
The award, when paid to the county treasurer, acts as a substitute for the condemned property.
Morton Grove Park Dist. v. American Nat’l Bank, 78 Ill. 2d 353, 399 N.E.2d 1295, 1298 (1980); Sanitary Dist. v. Schuster, 177 Ill. 626, 631 (1899); City of Chicago v. Gage, 268 Ill. 232, 239, 109 N.E. 28, 31 (1915); Crystal Lake Park Dist. v. Consumers’ Co., 313 Ill. 395, 399, 145 N.E. 215, 217 (1924). As a general principle, the person who is the owner of the property when possession is taken is entitled to the condemnation award.
In re Application of County Collector, 63 Ill. App. 3d 506, 377 N.E.2d 1230 (1st Dist. 1978); but see Department of Pub. Works v. Schmauss, 6 Ill. App. 3d 470, 285 N.E.2d 628, 630 (2d Dist. 1972) (right to compensation is fixed as of date of value). When there are several owners, just compensation is to be distributed among all persons with an interest in the property according to the fair value of their legal or equitable interests.
735 ILCS 30/10-5-90; Metropolitan W. Side Elevated Ry. v. Eschner, 232 Ill. 210, 214 (1908). There are thus two immediate questions to be determined: the title to the property and the relative value of any partial interests.

Where the complaint alleges that the property is owned by several persons, they are presumed to be tenants in common in the absence of evidence to the contrary.
Metropolitan W. Side Elevated Ry. v. Eschner, 232 Ill. 210, 213 (1908). While the averments of the complaint are binding on the condemnor, they do not bind the defendants.
Id. The various defendants may contest the presumption, but a party seeking apportionment of a condemnation award must allege an interest in the condemned property,
City of Chicago v. American Nat’l Bank, 233 Ill. App. 3d 1031, 1035, 599 N.E.2d 1126, 1129 (1st Dist. 1992). and then submit evidence to the court if the allegation is denied. It is the court, not the jury, which resolves disputed issues of title. The trier of fact determines the value of the interests, but does not determine questions of title. Those are preliminary matters for the court.
Illinois C. R. Co. v. Roskemmer, 264 Ill. 103, 105 N.E. 695, 696 (1914); Chicago & N.W. R. Co. v. Miller, 251 Ill. 58, 95 N.E. 1027, 1029 (1911).

Sometimes a condemnor finds itself embroiled in an already existing title dispute when it files an eminent domain action. If there is no litigation pending to resolve the dispute when the eminent domain suit is filed, the eminent domain court may resolve the title dispute itself.
Chicago & N. W. R. Co. v. Miller, 251 Ill. 58, 63, 95 N.E. 1027, 1029 (1911). However, if there is litigation already pending over title when the eminent domain suit is filed, the ruling of the court which already has jurisdiction over the title dispute controls the payment of the condemnation award.
735 ILCS 30/10-5-70(a); Crystal Lake Park Dist. v. Consumers’ Co., 313 Ill. 395, 399, 145 N.E. 215 (1924); Eddleman v. Union County Traction & Power Co., 217 Ill. 409, 421 (1905); Chicago v. Gage, 268 Ill. 232, 109 N.E. 28, 31 (1915); McCormick v. Park Comm’rs, 118 Ill. 655, 662 (1886) (error to order award paid into court as an interpleader, instead of to county treasurer).

It is sometimes said that issues of title must be resolved before the jury is impanelled,
Department of Pub. Works v. Smith, 61 Ill. App. 2d 301, 209 N.E.2d 666 (2d Dist. 1965) (abst.) (court properly determined whether State had an easement by prescription over existing right of way which had never previously been dedicated or condemned). with the parties litigating and settling their interests in the property before the court so that the jury can then determine the amount to be paid to each person interested in the property.
Chicago v. Gage, 268 Ill. 232, 109 N.E.2d 28, 31 (1915). But that is too broad a statement. If questions of title cannot be resolved before trial, then the apportionment of the award can be deferred, with the funds placed on deposit with the county treasurer pending a final adjudication of the questions of title.
Chicago & N. W. R. Co. v. Miller, 251 Ill. 58, 95 N.E. 1027, 1029 (1911); City of Chicago v. Gage, 268 Ill. 232, 239, 109 N.E. 28, 31 (1915); Metropolitan W. Side Elevated Ry. v. Eschner, 232 Ill. 210, 214 (1908).

Once issues of title are resolved, the individual interests in the property must be valued. Where there are multiple interests in property, the trier of fact must determine the respective values of each, and then apportion the total condemnation award among them.
Department of Pub. Works v. Schmauss, 6 Ill. App. 3d 470, 285 N.E.2d 628, 631 (2d Dist. 1972); Forest Preserve Dist. of Cook County v. Collins, 348 Ill. 477, 483, 181 N.E. 345 (1932); Chicago, Burlington & Quincy R.R. v. F. Reisch & Bros., 247 Ill. 350, 353, 93 N.E. 383 (1910); City of Vandalia v. Tate, 66 Ill. App. 2d 488, 491–92, 213 N.E.2d 787, 789 (5th Dist. 1966). A single award of just compensation for the condemned property typically is first made, and then the award is apportioned among all parties having an interest in the property according to the value of each interest.
City of Rockford v. Robert Hallen, Inc., 51 Ill. App. 3d 22, 366 N.E.2d 977, 979 (2d Dist. 1977); Board of Trustees v. Timpone, 28 Ill. 2d 255, 190 N.E.2d 786, 788 (1963). One court has called for a bifurcated proceeding, in which the jury first determines the value of the whole that was taken, and then, in a separate hearing, decides how to apportion the award.
Department of Transp. v. White, 264 Ill. App. 3d 145, 151, 636 N.E.2d 1204, 1208 (5th Dist. 1994); County of St. Clair v. Faust, 278 Ill. App. 3d 152, 156, 662 N.E.2d 584, 587 (5th Dist. 1996).

When there are multiple interests in the property taken, the amount of the total award is based upon the fair cash market value of the condemned property considered as a whole, and not upon the value of each interest therein.
Department of Pub. Works v. Schmauss, 6 Ill. App. 3d 470, 285 N.E.2d 628, 630 (2d Dist. 1972); City of Vandalia v. Tate, 66 Ill. App. 2d 488, 213 N.E.2d 787, 789 (5th Dist. 1966); Forest Preserve Dist. of Cook County v. Collins, 348 Ill. 477, 483, 181 N.E. 345 (1932). It is important to remember this approach, especially when drafting instruments which determine rights to the award, because valuing the whole as a unit instead of as the sum of the individual interests may mean that the value of the whole is less than the sum of the parts.

The condemnor is in a peculiar position when it comes to apportioning the award, for it has no direct interest in the money.
See Housing Auth. for LaSalle County v. Young Men’s Christian Ass’n of Ottawa, 101 Ill. 2d 246, 253, 461 N.E.2d 959, 962–63 (1984) (characterizing eminent domain proceeding as akin to interpleader action); but see Department of Transp. v. Heritage-Pullman Bank, 254 Ill. App. 3d 823, 826–827, 627 N.E.2d 191, 193 (1st Dist. 1993) (“[W]e are unable to determine what interest, if any, plaintiff has in the apportionment of final just compensation.”). However, it will typically monitor the proceedings to make sure that the right party receives the funds. If an award is paid to a person who is not the one actually entitled to the funds, the true claimant has an action against the entity which incorrectly paid the funds, as well as against the pretender recipient.
Yellow Cab Co. v. Howard, 243 Ill. App. 263, 275 (1st Dist. 1927). If the condemning body incorrectly paid the funds, it is bound to pay again to the proper claimant,
South Park Comm’rs v. Todd, 112 Ill. 379, 383 (1884). or else the taking will not be effective as against that claimant.
Bartlow v. Chicago, B. & Q. R. Co., 243 Ill. 332, 336, 90 N.E. 721 (1909). Whatever settlement the condemning body may make with one claimant is not binding on the others. The jury will not be instructed to deduct the amounts agreed to by a settling claimant from the award to the remaining claimants.
Chicago, Burlington & Quincy R.R. v. F. Reisch & Bros., 247 Ill. 350, 353, 93 N.E. 383 (1910).

The oath of the jurors calls for them to determine just compensation as to each party interested in the property,
735 ILCS 30/10-5-40. and the jury verdict must clearly set forth “the compensation ascertained to each person thereto entitled.”
735 ILCS 30/10-5-45. It therefore appears that a jury trial to determine an individual claimant’s compensation is a matter of right.
Chicago & N. W. R. Co. v. Miller, 251 Ill. 58, 63, 95 N.E. 1027, 1029 (1911) (tenant claimant; however, jury trial not available if it would impinge on another court’s jurisdiction to resolve a title dispute); see Commercial Delivery Serv., Inc. v. Medema, 7 Ill. App. 2d 419, 423, 129 N.E.2d 579, 580 (1st Dist. 1955); and Department of Transp. v. Mullen, 120 Ill. App. 3d 268, 279, 457 N.E.2d 1362, 1369 (4th Dist. 1983) (parties’ failure to request separate jury apportionment waived any right). Thus, the same jury which determines the amount of the total award may determine the amount of the individual claimant’s compensation. This can be done in the same trial that determines the amount of just compensation for the whole property. As would the court, the jury first fixes the value of the property and then divides the award among the claimants.
Lambert v. Giffin, 257 Ill. 152, 158, 100 N.E. 496, 499 (1913); Chicago, Burlington & Quincy R.R. v. F. Reisch, 247 Ill. 350, 353 (1910).

Where there is no averment of a lesser title or of any encumbrance, the defendants are regarded as owners of unencumbered title in fee simple.
Metropolitan W. Side Elevated Ry. v. Eschner, 232 Ill. 210, 213 (1908). But interests less than the total fee must also be considered. Holders of liens on, or rights against, the property then have a lien against the award.
City of Chicago v. Gage, 268 Ill. 232, 239, 109 N.E. 28, 31 (1915); City of Chicago v. McCausland, 379 Ill. 602, 41 N.E.2d 745, 747 (1942); Thomas v. St. Louis, B. & S. R. Co., 164 Ill. 634, 636, 46 N.E. 8 (1897) (vendor’s lien). The order of lien priority which held against the taken property remains unchanged.
Chicago Land Clearance Comm’n v. Narodski, 57 Ill. App. 2d 302, 207 N.E.2d 81, 82 (1st Dist. 1965). The lesser interests compensable in a condemnation include leaseholds,
Department of Transp. v. Mullen, 120 Ill. App. 3d 268, 279, 457 N.E.2d 1362, 1367 (4th Dist. 1983); Corrigan v. City of Chicago, 144 Ill. 537, 543, 33 N.E. 746, 747 (1893); Stubbings v. Village of Evanston, 136 Ill. 37, 43, 26 N.E. 577, 578 (1891); City of Chicago v. American Nat’l Bank, 233 Ill. App. 3d 1031, 1035, 599 N.E.2d 1126, 1129 (1st Dist. 1992). including mineral leaseholds where the lessee pays a royalty interest instead of fixed rent.
Department of Pub. Works v. Blackberry Union Cemetery, 32 Ill. App. 3d 62, 65, 335 N.E.2d 577, 579–580 (2d Dist. 1975). The law protects parties who do not have possessory rights, such as contract purchasers, mortgagees, tax purchasers and lessors; in addition, parties may by contract agree upon a different allocation of the award.

tr:secsub1.core:title: Vendor-Purchaser.
tr:secsub1.core:para:
Property subject to condemnation may be sold. Although the effect of an eminent domain filing on marketability of the property can be devastating, there are still circumstances where private buyers may wish to purchase the property which is encumbered with the condemnation lawsuit. This is especially true where the condemnation is only a partial taking, and the remainder is economically viable. If a sale takes place after the eminent domain proceeding is filed but before title vests, the award is payable to the purchaser, unless the parties involved have otherwise agreed.
In re DOT, 173 Ill. App. 3d 730, 732, 527 N.E.2d 958, 960 (1st Dist. 1988). If the property is sold after the public improvement is constructed, it is presumed that the grantor was compensated and the grantee received a reduction in price. The grantee has no additional claim for just compensation, even if no eminent domain suit was ever filed, unless a new improvement is constructed.
Wabash, St. Louis & Pac. Ry. v. McDougall, 118 Ill. 229, 236 (1886).

Where a contract for deed is in place before the condemnation, the contract is abrogated by the filing of the eminent domain action. From the condemnation award, the purchaser receives the down payment, and the total monthly payments made on the contract (less interest and an amount equal to fair rental value), plus the cost of improvements which increased the value of the premises; the seller receives the rest. Alternatively, the purchaser may pay the remaining amount due on the contract to the seller, and receive the entire award.
735 ILCS 30/10-5-90.

In the case of a sale of property subject to a partial taking, the sale of the remainder must also consider the right to recover damages. This right may be assigned. The right to damages is considered a chose in action which can be assigned so long as the intent to vest ownership in the right to recover damages is sufficiently demonstrated.
See, e.g., Department of Transp. v. Heritage-Pullman Bank, 254 Ill. App. 3d 823, 826, 627 N.E.2d 191, 192–93 (1st Dist. 1993).

Oftentimes, real estate sales contracts or option agreements condition rights upon sale of the property to a third party. A condemnation apparently does not qualify as such a sale. Although the terms of the specific agreement control, the differences between an involuntary condemnation and a voluntary, arm’s-length transaction have been enough to deny a claimant any rights to an award based on such an agreement.
Forest Preserve Dist. of Du Page County v. Brookwood Land Venture, 229 Ill. App. 3d 978, 983, 595 N.E.2d 136, 141 (2d Dist. 1992).

tr:secsub1.core:title: Mortgages.
tr:secsub1.core:para:
The holder of a first mortgage is a proper party to be awarded a portion of the condemnation proceeds.
Village of Rosemont v. Maywood-Proviso State Bank, 149 Ill. App. 3d 1087, 1091, 501 N.E.2d 859, 862 (1st Dist. 1986). The property under condemnation is taken by the condemnor free of the mortgage lien, but the mortgagee has an equitable lien on the award.
Department of Transp. v. New Century Eng’g & Dev. Corp., 97 Ill. 2d 343, 350, 454 N.E.2d 635, 639 (1983); Sanitary Dist. v. Schuster, 177 Ill. 626, 631–32 (1899); City of Chicago v. Salinger, 384 Ill. 515, 519, 52 N.E.2d 184, 187 (1943); City of Chicago v. Gage, 268 Ill. 232, 239, 109 N.E. 28 (1915). The lien follows the fund, which is a substitute for the land.
Calumet R. R. Co. v. Brown, 136 Ill. 322, 331, 26 N.E. 501 (1891). This lien has priority over the claims to the award of the mortgagor or any subsequent judgment creditor.
Village of Clarendon Hills v. Mulder, 278 Ill. App. 3d 727, 736, 663 N.E.2d 435, 442–443 (2d Dist. 1996); City of Chicago v. Salinger, 384 Ill. 515, 519, 52 N.E.2d 184, 187 (1943); South Park Comm’rs v. Todd, 112 Ill. 379, 383 (1884). The rationale underlying the mortgagee’s right to an equitable lien was imported from a Michigan court:

core:blockquote.core:blockquote-para:
The underlying theory of the right of the mortgagee to part or all of the award is that, as the parties are powerless to prevent the taking of the property by the public and the mortgagee loses his lien upon the part taken, the award equitably stands in the place of the land taken; and, as the mortgage does not cover the award in law, it is held to operate as an equitable lien thereon. This results in two separate encumbrances, the legal mortgage lien on the remainder of the land and the equitable mortgage lien on the award.
City of Chicago v. Salinger, 384 Ill. 515, 520, 52 N.E.2d 184, 187 (1943) (citing In re Dillman, 276 Mich. 252, 267 N.W. 623, 625 (1936)).

tr:secsub1.core:para:
It is not completely clear whether the mortgagee is directly entitled to the condemnation award. If the mortgagee forecloses on its lien, the award can clearly be applied against the debt.
Department of Transp. v. New Century Eng’g & Dev. Corp., 97 Ill. 2d 343, 350, 454 N.E.2d 635, 639 (1983). Even if not, it may be that no foreclosure proceeding is necessary to reach the money. One case held that the mortgagee need merely file a petition to the eminent domain court to receive the award.
City of Chicago v. Salinger, 384 Ill. 515, 521, 52 N.E.2d 184, 187 (1943). Probably the typical practice is to consult the mortgage document itself for the proper procedure. Because condemnation results in an involuntary transfer of property, performance of a prepayment penalty in a mortgage will be excused unless there is clear language which expressly delineates payment of a premium upon condemnation.
Village of Rosemont v. Maywood-Proviso State Bank, 149 Ill. App. 3d 1087, 1092, 501 N.E.2d 859, 862 (1st Dist. 1986).

tr:secsub1.core:title: Tax Purchase.
tr:secsub1.core:para:
When real estate is sold for failure to pay taxes, the tax purchaser at first receives just a certificate of purchase. The tax deed issues only after the redemption period expires. When a condemnation intervenes before the redemption period expires, no tax deed can issue.
Chicago Land Clearance Comm’n v. Narodski, 57 Ill. App. 2d 302, 305 n.2, 207 N.E.2d 81, 83 n.2 (1st Dist. 1965). The eminent domain proceeding also makes it impossible for the owner to redeem. To insure that the fortuitous circumstance of condemnation does not work a windfall for either the owner or the tax purchaser, the award is first paid to the tax purchaser in the amount necessary to redeem, with the rest of the award, if any, then paid to the owner.
Delano, Inc. v. Arnold, 46 Ill. 2d 498, 263 N.E.2d 830, 831 (1970).

tr:secsub2.core:title: In General.
tr:secsub2.core:para:
A lost leasehold is compensable.
Department of Transp. v. Singh, 393 Ill. App. 3d 458, 468, 914 N.E.2d 511, 519 (2d Dist. 2009). Tenants under a valid leasehold hold such a valid interest in the property to be classified as owners in the constitutional sense and are entitled to compensation.
Public Building Commission v. Yellen, 2013 IL App (1st) 112638, ¶ 33, 986 N.E.2d 706, 715. A lessee takes and holds for the term of the lease just like an owner of property, in that the tenancy is subject to the sovereign’s right to take.
Leonard v. Autocar Sales & Serv. Co., 392 Ill. 182, 191, 64 N.E.2d 477, 481 (1945). A taking does not constitute a breach of the lease’s covenant of quiet enjoyment, and does not amount to an eviction.
Corrigan v. City of Chicago, 144 Ill. 537, 543, 33 N.E. 746, 747 (1893). Where a condemning authority takes a fee interest in real property but the fee is encumbered by a lease which is not taken, the amount of the just compensation award is still a sum equivalent to the fair cash market value of the fee on the valuation date.
Department of Pub. Works v. Bohne, 415 Ill. 253, 264, 113 N.E.2d 319, 325 (1953).

Lease termination must be considered in the context of eminent domain. Where the lease expired after the condemnation suit was filed, but before the date of taking—determined to be once the just compensation was paid and the condemnor had taken possession—the tenant had no right to the award.
Department of Transp. v. Singh, 393 Ill. App. 3d 458, 468, 914 N.E.2d 511, 519 (2d Dist. 2009). Public Building Commission v. Yellen, 2013 IL App (1st) 112638, ¶¶ 36–37, 986 N.E.2d 706, 715. And, where a tenant was in default after the eminent domain suit was commenced, a five-day notice served to terminate the lease; the tenant was thereafter not entitled to any portion of the award of just compensation.
Village of Palatine v. Palatine Associates, LLC, 2012 IL App (1st) 102707, ¶ 58, 966 N.E.2d 1174, 1190.

Where the government takes the entire property, both the landlord and the tenant receive just compensation, although from the same source. The money awarded stands in lieu of the property taken, and is apportioned among the several interests in the property.
Corrigan v. City of Chicago, 144 Ill. 537, 545, 33 N.E. 746, 748 (1893). The award is divided between the landlord and tenant according to their respective interests.
City of Rockford v. Robert Hallen, Inc., 51 Ill. App. 3d 22, 366 N.E.2d 977, 979 (2d Dist. 1977); Department of Transp. v. Gass, 165 Ill. App. 3d 562, 566, 519 N.E.2d 90, 93 (5th Dist. 1988). Tenants who hold under leases which are not recorded may end up not being named as defendants in the eminent domain proceeding. Such tenants may intervene in the eminent domain proceeding or may proceed outside the statute in an action directly against the named defendants who recovered the tenant’s share as well as their own.
Yellow Cab Co. v. Howard, 243 Ill. App. 263, 276 (1st Dist. 1927).

The tenant usually draws out its share of the award first, because it holds the present possessory interest in the property pursuant to the lease and the landlord’s interest is merely a reversionary interest.
Milton R. Friedman, Friedman on Leases § 13.3 (3d ed. 1990). This being the case, it is clear that the interests of the landlord and the tenant with respect to the condemnation award may be adverse to each other, since the greater the amount the tenant recovers from the award, the less remains to compensate the landlord. But the fates of the landlord and tenant are not always inextricable. Though they are usually tied together, a verdict as to one may be overturned without necessarily overturning the verdict for the other.
Stubbings v. Village of Evanston, 136 Ill. 37, 44, 26 N.E. 577, 578 (1891).

tr:secsub3.core:title: In General.
tr:secsub3.core:para:
If there is no condemnation clause in the lease, the award is divided according to common law rules.
Department of Pub. Works v. Metropolitan Life Ins. Co., 42 Ill. App. 2d 378, 385, 192 N.E.2d 607, 611 (1st Dist. 1963); United States v. Advertising Checking Bur., Inc., 204 F.2d 770, 772 (7th Cir. 1953); see 42 U.S.C. § 4601 et seq. The common law distinguishes five ways in which a leasehold can be affected by condemnation and establishes different rules to govern the rights of the landlord and the tenant in each case. Also, in some cases statutory law may give the tenant additional rights, such as the right to recover moving expenses.

tr:secsub3.core:title: Entire Leased Premises Taken.
tr:secsub3.core:para:
Under Illinois common law, when both the fee interest subject to a lease and the leasehold are taken by condemnation, the leasehold estate terminates by operation of law, because the condemnor has become both the lessor and the lessee after the taking.
Corrigan v. City of Chicago, 144 Ill. 537, 544–545, 33 N.E. 746, 747 (1893). The legal fiction that the taking relates back to the date of filing can cause confusion as to the tenant’s obligation to pay rent, and to whom. Equitable considerations have led the courts to conclude that the obligation of the tenant to pay rent continues until the date on which the judgment is paid (and possession transfers to the condemnor), thus allowing title to vest in the condemnor while the landlord can still collect rents while the condemnation suit is pending.
Bohne v. Bauer, 21 Ill. App. 2d 133, 135 (2d Dist. 1959); Corrigan v. City of Chicago, 144 Ill. 537, 548, 33 N.E. 746, 749 (1893). Once possession is transferred, of course, the obligation to pay rent ceases entirely.

The extent of the lessee’s interest is the value of the term, subject to the rents the lessee must pay.
Corrigan v. City of Chicago, 144 Ill. 537, 548, 33 N.E. 746, 749 (1893). The measure of the tenant’s loss is the fair cash market value of the leasehold, which is measured as the difference between the fair rental value of the premises and the rent reserved under the lease.
Department of Pub. Works v. Bohne, 415 Ill. 253, 262–263, 113 N.E.2d 319, 324 (1953). Fair rental value must necessarily be determined in calculating the value of the leasehold. Like fair cash market value, fair rental value assumes the hypothetical willing persons in the market; in this case, the hypothetical landlord and tenant. Fair rental value is the amount of rent a tenant willing to rent would pay to an owner willing to lease, with neither being under any compulsion to act.
Illinois Pattern Jury Instructions, Civil No. 300.83. Fair rental value can be proven by opinion evidence or by evidence of comparable rents.
Commercial Delivery Serv., Inc. v. Medema, 7 Ill. App. 2d 419, 424–425, 129 N.E. 2d 579, 581 (1st Dist. 1955).

The tenant suffers an actual economic loss in the case of a full taking only where the rent reserved to be paid under the lease is less than the fair market rental for the leased premises. Termination of the lease by condemnation deprives the tenant of the benefit of its below-market, or “bonus,” lease, i.e., the advantage the tenant enjoys by paying less rent than others would pay, and the law seeks to compensate the tenant for this deprivation.
Department of Pub. Works v. Blackberry Union Cemetery, 32 Ill. App. 3d 62, 65, 335 N.E.2d 577, 580 (2d Dist. 1975). The notion of “bonus value” to a below-market lease is well-recognized. See, e.g., St. Louis County v. Boatmen’s Trust Co., 857 S.W.2d 453, 456 (Mo. App. 1993). Accordingly, in a full taking, the tenant’s share of the award is the amount by which the fair cash market value of the right to use and occupy the property under the lease exceeds the amount of rent the tenant is required to pay under the lease.
Corrigan v. City of Chicago, 144 Ill. 537, 548–549, 33 N.E. 746, 749 (1893).

As an example of this bonus value, consider a situation in which the annual fair market rental on the date of value is $1,500, but the rent under the lease is only $1,000 per year. The tenant is entitled to recover: $1,500 − $1,000 = $500 bonus value for each year remaining in the term (discounted to present value on the date of the award). On the other hand, if the rent reserved under the lease is greater than or equal to the fair market rent, the tenant suffers no compensable leasehold loss from termination of the lease by condemnation and is therefore not entitled to recover from the award for its leasehold.

An option to renew the lease can enhance the fair market value of the leasehold by significantly increasing the length of the lease and thereby the period of time in which the bonus can be realized. In determining the value of the leasehold, the option period apparently may also be considered.
Department of Pub. Works v. Bohne, 415 Ill. 253, 256, 113 N.E.2d 319, 324 (1953) (market value of ten-year lease was effectively enhanced to extent of ten-year option period).

After the tenant has recovered the portion of the award to which it is entitled, the remainder of the award belongs to the landlord. If the property taken has been correctly valued, the landlord’s share should be equal to: (1) the present value of the rents reserved for the remainder of the term, plus (2) the present value of the landlord’s reversionary interest in the property.
Department of Pub. Works v. Metropolitan Life Ins. Co., 42 Ill. App. 2d 378, 387, 192 N.E.2d 607, 612 (1st Dist. 1963); Corrigan v. City of Chicago, 144 Ill. 537, 545, 33 N.E. 746, 748 (1893). The latter is determined by establishing a sum which, if deposited now at compound interest, would result in the landlord receiving the amount of the landlord’s loss upon termination of the lease.
Department of Pub. Works v. Metropolitan Life Ins. Co., 42 Ill. App. 2d 378, 388, 192 N.E.2d 607, 612 (1st Dist. 1963). Accurate valuation, of course, is always a risk in litigation. Both juries and judges may make a substantive mistake in reaching the valuation decision. Due to the large range of discretion given to the finder of just compensation, a valuation within the range of evidence may be upheld even if incorrect, as long as it has been objectively considered. The landlord bears the risk of inaccurate valuation, especially where the total award is set and the claims apportioned in a separate proceeding.

In addition, at times the law will not even attempt a valuation of the landlord’s interest. Illinois law states that attaching a value to the landlord’s reversionary interest where there is a long-term lease is mere speculation. It therefore assigns no value to the reversion in such a case.
Chicago & N.W. Ry. v. Chicago Mech. Inst., 239 Ill. 197, 221, 87 N.E. 933, 943 (1909). The courts have not precisely defined what constitutes a long-term lease for purposes of declining to value the landlord’s reversion. A lease for 999 years is clearly long-term.
Chicago W. Div. Ry. v. Metropolitan W. Side Elevated R.R., 152 Ill. 519, 526 (1894). A 99-year lease having 95 years left to run in the term has been called a long-term lease with a valueless reversion.
Department of Pub. Works v. Metropolitan Life Ins. Co., 42 Ill. App. 2d 378, 388, 192 N.E.2d 607, 612 (1st Dist. 1963). As the length of time remaining on the lease decreases, the courts are more reluctant to call it a long-term lease. Thus, an 80-year lease
Chicago & N.W. Ry. v. Chicago Mech. Inst., 239 Ill. 197, 221, 87 N.E. 933, 943 (1909). and a 50-year lease
Yellow Cab Co. v. Howard, 243 Ill. App. 263, 280 (1st Dist. 1927). have been treated as long-term, but a 26-year lease has been called a medium-term lease.
Department of Pub. Works v. Metropolitan Life Ins. Co., 42 Ill. App. 2d 378, 385, 192 N.E.2d 607, 611 (1st Dist. 1963) (citing Corrigan v. City of Chicago, 144 Ill. 537, 33 N.E. 746 (1893)). The evidence in one case indicated that the reversionary interest in a lease was treated as valueless unless the lease only had ten to fifteen years to run.
Chicago & N.W. Ry. v. Chicago Mech. Inst., 239 Ill. 197, 219, 87 N.E. 933, 943 (1909).

tr:secsub4.core:title: In General.
tr:secsub4.core:para:
A taking of only a portion of the leased premises is a partial taking, because there is a remainder left over. Even though the remainder itself is a leasehold, the same rules of valuation and apportionment generally apply. A tenant’s compensation for a partial taking is an amount equal to the value of the tenant’s estate in the strip taken, and an amount equal to the damage, if any, done to the tenant’s estate in the portion of the property not taken.
Stubbings v. Village of Evanston, 136 Ill. 37, 43, 26 N.E. 577, 578 (1891).

tr:secsub4.core:title: Remainder Not Capable of Further Use.
tr:secsub4.core:para:
Where the fee interest in only a portion of the leased premises is taken and the portion of the premises remaining is not subject to use and occupancy as intended under the lease, the condemnation is treated as a full taking and the award is distributed accordingly.
Yellow Cab Co. v. Stafford-Smith, 320 Ill. 294, 296, 150 N.E. 670, 671 (1926).

tr:secsub4.core:title: Usable Remainder.
tr:secsub4.core:para:
Where the fee interest in only a portion of the leased premises is taken but the portion of the premises not taken can still be used as intended under the lease, the lease continues in full force as to the part not taken, and there is no abatement or apportionment of rent under the lease.
Leonard v. Autocar Sales & Serv. Co., 392 Ill. 182, 195, 64 N.E.2d 477, 483 (1945); Yellow Cab Co. v. Stafford-Smith, 320 Ill. 294, 296, 150 N.E. 670, 671 (1926); Corrigan v. City of Chicago, 144 Ill. 537, 544, 33 N.E. 746, 747 (1893); Stubbings v. Evanston, 136 Ill. 37, 43, 26 N.E. 577, 578 (1891).

The result of this rule is that, after condemnation, the tenant is required to pay the same amount of rent as originally set forth in the lease, but is entitled only to the use and occupancy of a smaller parcel of property than was originally contemplated. The law seeks to protect a tenant from this inequity by permitting the tenant to recover out of the condemnation award an amount equal to the fair cash market value of the leasehold estate in the condemned portion of the leased premises, plus the amount required to compensate the tenant for the continuing obligation to pay rent.
Department of Pub. Works v. Blackberry Union Cemetery, 32 Ill. App. 3d 62, 65, 335 N.E.2d 577, 579 (2d Dist. 1975); Department of Pub. Works v. Metropolitan Life Ins. Co., 42 Ill. App. 2d 378, 389, 192 N.E.2d 607, 613 (1st Dist. 1963).

After a partial taking of leased premises, the landlord continues to be entitled to collect the rent set forth in the lease; therefore, the landlord’s recovery in a partial taking is limited to the present value of its reversionary interest in the portion of the premises taken.
Department of Pub. Works v. Metropolitan Life Ins. Co., 42 Ill. App. 2d 378, 390, 192 N.E.2d 607, 613 (1st Dist. 1963).

tr:secsub3.core:title: Entire Leasehold Term Taken, but Not Fee.
tr:secsub3.core:para: Sometimes private property is required and taken for public use only temporarily. The best examples occur during wartime. In such situations, the government may seek to acquire the temporary use of property by eminent domain. When the property the government seeks to condemn temporarily is already under lease, the effect is to condemn a leasehold. The taking should be treated as a temporary, partial condemnation and the rules governing just compensation and damages in partial takings condemnation should govern. If the remainder of the premises is capable of occupation as intended under the lease, the tenant’s obligation to pay rent should continue unabated and the tenant should be entitled to recover the fair cash market value of its leasehold interest in the part taken, plus the damage to its interest in the remainder. The landlord suffers no damages so long as the tenant’s obligation to pay rent continues unabated, because the landlord retains its reversionary interest in the property.

tr:secsub3.core:title: Portion of Leasehold Term Taken, but Not Fee.
tr:secsub3.core:para: One form of a partial taking of a leased premises is a taking of the leasehold for a limited period of time. The normal rules for analyzing a partial taking apply, although the extent of the part taken and the remainder is defined by time instead of territorial scope.

One significant ancillary difference between the taking of all of a leasehold and the taking of a leasehold for a limited period of time is the impact on the obligation to pay rent. To terminate the obligation to pay rent, the interests of the tenant and of the landlord must be merged and extinguished. If the government condemns only a portion of a lease term, the tenant’s obligation to pay rent continues unaffected.
Leonard v. Autocar Sales & Serv. Co., 392 Ill. 182, 195, 64 N.E.2d 477, 483 (1945). This obligation now becomes the governments’s as the new tenant. In addition, the condemnor is required to pay to the original tenant, as just compensation for the temporary taking of the tenant’s leasehold interest, the present discounted value of the rental which would be set in free negotiation between a long-term tenant of similar space and a sublessee seeking temporary occupancy thereof.

Elements of damage peculiar to the tenant, such as loss of good will, generally are not considered in setting the fair market rental discussed above. Loss of good will and going concern value may be compensable, however, where the condemnor acquires business property with the intention of carrying on the tenant’s business to such an extent that the owner may not relocate.
Kimball Laundry Co. v. United States, 338 U.S. 1, 15, 69 S. Ct. 1434, 1442, 93 L. Ed. 1765 (1949). In such a case, if the condemnor acquires goodwill or going concern value, it must pay for it.
Id.

tr:secsub2.core:title: Condemnation Lease Provision.
tr:secsub2.core:para:
The landlord and the tenant are free to make their own arrangements regarding the effect of a condemnation. Parties can include a clause in a contract governing their rights to compensation in the event of a condemnation proceeding.
Department of Transportation v. 600 West Dundee, LLC, 2019 IL App (1st) 181699, ¶ 7, 129 N.E.3d 654, 657 (no part of compensation awarded to tenant where sole remedy in case of a partial taking was rent adjustment); Village of Palatine v. Palatine Associates, LLC, 406 Ill. App. 3d 973, 980–81, 942 N.E.2d 10, 17 (1st Dist. 2010) (lease assigned entire award to landlord unless there was a specific award to tenant for its trade fixtures, but there was no such specific award, and tenant received no portion of the condemnation award). Agreements between the landlord and tenant which apportion the condemnation award differently than it would be under common law will be enforced.
Department of Transportation v. 600 West Dundee, LLC, 2019 IL App (1st) 181699, ¶ 7, 129 N.E.3d 654, 657 (lease language “dictates [tenant]’s rights in the event of a condemnation proceeding”); Department of Pub. Works v. Metropolitan Life Ins. Co., 42 Ill. App. 2d 378, 385, 192 N.E.2d 607, 611 (1st Dist. 1963); United States v. Advertising Checking Bur. Inc., 204 F.2d 770, 772–73 (7th Cir. 1953). The normal rules of contract interpretation apply.
Department of Transportation v. 600 West Dundee, LLC, 2019 IL App (1st) 181699, ¶ 8, 129 N.E.3d 654, 657. No particular arrangement is favored by the courts, or required. One way the parties typically reapportion the award is by providing that the lease will terminate as to any portion of the leased premises taken by condemnation (either automatically or at the election of one or both parties) and also providing for equitable adjustment of the rent accordingly. If the lease provides for termination in the event of condemnation, the tenant takes the leased premises for the stated term or such shorter term as may be set by condemnation, and hence will not be entitled to claim that its leasehold interest has been damaged by condemnation (and will not be entitled to compensation therefor out of the award).
Select Lake City Theatre Oper. Co. v. Central Nat’l Bank, 277 F.2d 814, 817–18 (7th Cir. 1960). A provision terminating the lease in the event of condemnation has the effect of distributing more of the award to the landlord than would be the case under the common law.

A landlord who knows of a forthcoming condemnation must inform the prospective tenant before a lease is signed or else risk being found guilty of fraud and having the lease equitably reformed to remove the termination clause.
City of Chicago v. American Nat’l Bank, 233 Ill. App. 3d 1031, 1037, 599 N.E.2d 1126, 1131 (1st Dist. 1992); Forest Preserve Dist. of Cook County v. Christopher, 321 Ill. App. 91, 104–106, 52 N.E.2d 313, 319 (1st Dist. 1943). A tenant which voluntarily terminates its lease after the condemnation action is filed, before the natural termination of the lease but before the award is deposited, does so at that tenant’s peril.
City of Lake Forest v. First Nat’l Bank of Lake Forest, 52 Ill. App. 3d 893, 895, 368 N.E.2d 156, 158 (2d Dist. 1977). It may lose any claim to the award.

Certain additional issues should generally be addressed in the provision of the lease dealing with condemnation. For instance, if the parties desire the lease term to continue after a partial condemnation, the lease should indicate who will be responsible for restoring the remainder of the leased premises and whether the proceeds of the condemnation award will go to restoration.

The parties may also provide a formula for equitable adjustment of the rent if the lease will continue after a partial taking. Milton Friedman has suggested a formula for adjusting the rent in a way that preserves the original bargain of the parties by setting the new rent at the same level relative to the value of the leased premises as was the rent prior to condemnation.
Milton R. Friedman, Friedman on Leases § 13.5 (3d ed. 1990). Friedman’s formula is:

tr:secsub2.core:para: Because condemnation proceedings are often forestalled by an agreed sale to the condemning authority, a lease providing that the tenant is entitled to share in the condemnation award can also make clear that the tenant shall have the same rights with regard to the proceeds of a sale in lieu of condemnation. In such a case, the tenant may also desire to have the right to participate in negotiations for a sale in lieu of condemnation.

tr:secsub2.core:title: Tenant’s Improvements and Fixtures.
tr:secsub2.core:para:
Another potential element of the tenant’s loss from a condemnation is the value of the tenant’s improvements and fixtures. The fair cash market value of the leasehold should reflect any enhancement attributable to leasehold improvements.
Department of Pub. Works v. Bohne, 415 Ill. 253, 263, 113 N.E.2d 319, 325 (1953). The law requires that the tenant be compensated for the value of improvements and fixtures if they are actually taken by the condemning authority, although whether an article is a fixture for which compensation is required depends on the facts and circumstances of the particular case.
Empire Bldg. Corp. v. Orput & Assocs., 32 Ill. App. 3d 839, 840, 336 N.E.2d 82, 84 (2d Dist. 1975); Schreiber v. Chicago & E. R. Co., 115 Ill. 340, 346, 3 N.E. 427, 429 (1885); see also Department of Pub. Works v. Bohne, 415 Ill. 253, 263, 113 N.E.2d 319, 324 (1953). Note that the tenant can only recover for its fixtures and improvements if (a) they are taken, and (b) they are the tenant’s property. Accordingly, if the condemnor does not take the tenant’s fixtures and improvements, and the tenant retains the right to remove such items, the tenant is not entitled to compensation.
National R.R. Passenger Corp. v. Faber Enters., Inc., 931 F.2d 438, 443 (7th Cir. 1991). This is true even if the condemnation prevents the tenant from recovering the cost of its fixtures and improvements through its use of such improvements during the term of the lease.
Select Lake City Theatre Oper. Co. v. Central Nat’l Bank, 277 F.2d 814, 817 (7th Cir. 1960). If the lease provides that improvements made by the tenant shall become the property of the landlord, the compensation for their taking rightly belongs to the landlord rather than to the tenant.
National R.R. Passenger Corp. v. Faber Enters., Inc., 931 F.2d 438, 441 (7th Cir. 1991); Corrigan v. City of Chicago, 144 Ill. 537, 550, 33 N.E. 746, 749 (1893); Commercial Delivery Service, Inc. v. Medema, 7 Ill. App. 2d 419, 427, 129 N.E. 2d 579, 582 (1st Dist. 1955).

Where the tenant is entitled to be compensated for fixtures and improvements, the value attributed to those items will depend on whether the lease provides that it will be terminated by condemnation. The tenant cannot recover for the value of the right to use the improvements and fixtures for the full term of the lease (i.e., their value in place) if it has agreed that the lease will be terminated by condemnation.
Select Lake City Theatre Oper. Co. v. Central Nat’l Bank, 277 F.2d 814, 818 (7th Cir. 1960). If the lease provides that it is terminated by condemnation, then, in effect, the tenant has contracted for the right to use its improvements and fixtures during the stated term of the lease, as such term may be shortened by condemnation.
National R.R. Passenger Corp. v. Faber Enters., Inc., 931 F.2d 438, 443 (7th Cir. 1991). In such a case, what the condemnor has deprived the tenant of is the right to remove its improvements and fixtures on termination of the lease. The value of the right to remove improvements and fixtures from the leased premises is limited to the value on the date of condemnation of the improvements after removal from the leased premises (less the cost of removal).
Milton R. Friedman, Friedman on Leases § 13.4 (3d ed. 1990).

The tenant can protect its ability to recover the cost of its fixtures and improvements made to the leased premises by providing in the lease that the tenant shall be entitled to recover from the condemnation award an amount equal to the unamortized cost of its improvements on the date of condemnation. To avoid the cost and delay of proving the unamortized cost in a condemnation proceeding, the parties can set forth an amortization schedule in the lease. The landlord may object to such a provision on the grounds that the improvements made by the tenant will not increase the value of the fee (or the award), and therefore, if the tenant is permitted to recover the unamortized cost of its improvements, the effect will be to reduce the portion of the award going to the landlord with no commensurate increase in the total size of the award. The tenant, on the other hand, can argue that it will not make the improvements (which, in the likely event there is no condemnation, the landlord eventually will enjoy the benefits of) unless it receives some assurance that it will be able to recover the cost of the improvements either by using them for the expected term of the lease or by recovering the unamortized cost out of the condemnation award.

A trade fixture is personal property of the tenant that is affixed to the realty for purposes of carrying on the tenant’s business. To determine what is a trade fixture, courts consider (1) the means by which the item is affixed to the real estate, (2) whether it is adapted to and necessary for the purposes to which the premises is devoted, and (3) the intent of the parties. Items installed by the tenant are rebuttably presumed to be trade fixtures.
Village of Palatine v. Palatine Associates, LLC, 406 Ill. App. 3d 973, 979–80, 942 N.E.2d 10, 16 (1st Dist. 2010). A trade fixture is the tenant’s property and may be removed by the tenant so long as removal does not damage the realty; thus, unlike a fixture, which becomes part of the realty belonging to the landlord, compensation for a trade fixture taken by eminent domain is owed to the tenant.
Village of Palatine v. Palatine Associates, LLC, 406 Ill. App. 3d 973, 979–80, 942 N.E.2d 10, 16 (1st Dist. 2010).

Where trade fixtures were movable, they were not taken (because not specifically described in the complaint for condemnation), and the tenant was entitled to no compensation for them.
Village of Palatine v. Palatine Associates, LLC, 406 Ill. App. 3d 973, 981–82, 942 N.E.2d 10, 18 (1st Dist. 2010). And the tenant was not entitled to compensation for immovable trade fixtures, because they became property of the landlord when the lease terminated upon the taking.
Village of Palatine v. Palatine Associates, LLC, 406 Ill. App. 3d 973, 982–83, 942 N.E.2d 10, 19 (1st Dist. 2010).

tr:secsub2.core:title: Billboards.
tr:secsub2.core:para:
An amendment to the eminent domain statute expressly grants a right of just compensation to the owners of billboards. One court applied the plain meaning of this statute to a condemnation case, holding that the billboard owner was entitled to fair market value, not just “bonus value,” of the billboard.
Department of Transp. v. Drury Displays, Inc., 327 Ill. App. 3d 881, 888, 764 N.E.2d 166, 172 (5th Dist. 2002). Another court distinguished the first case and held that the billboard owner was only entitled to the “bonus value” of the billboard—the amount by which the value of the leasehold interest exceeds the rent covenanted to be paid.
Department of Transp. v. East Side Development, LLC, 384 Ill. App. 3d 295, 299–300, 892 N.E.2d 136, 140–141 (3d Dist. 2008). The court further held that the amendments to the eminent domain statute did not abrogate the “unit rule” of valuation of property with billboard improvements.
Department of Transp. v. East Side Development, LLC, 384 Ill. App. 3d 295, 300, 892 N.E.2d 136, 140 (3d Dist. 2008). Amortization is not an available alternative; the owner must receive just compensation.
City of Oakbrook Terrace v. Suburban Bank and Trust Co., 364 Ill. App. 3d 506, 518, 845 N.E.2d 1000, 1011 (2d Dist. 2006). However, where the billboard must be removed at the end of the term pursuant to the terms of the billboard lease, the statute does not apply.
Lamar Advantage G.P. Co. v. Addison Park Dist., 354 Ill. App. 3d 130, 141, 820 N.E.2d 626, 635–36 (2d Dist. 2004); CBS Outdoor, Inc. v. Village of Itasca, 2011 IL App (2d) 101117, ¶ 24, 960 N.E.2d 1212, 1218.

tr:secsub2.core:title: Attorney’s Fees.
tr:secsub2.core:para:
As the Illinois Supreme Court has long recognized, Illinois follows the “American rule” which prohibits prevailing parties from recovering their attorney’s fees from the losing party absent an express statute or contractual provision.
Forest Preserve Dist. of Cook County v. Continental Community Bank and Trust Co., 2017 IL App (1st) 170680, ¶ 31, 98 N.E.3d 459, 468. The fee-shifting statute or contract are construed to mean nothing more, but also nothing less, than the letter of the text.
Forest Preserve Dist. of Cook County v. Continental Community Bank and Trust Co., 2017 IL App (1st) 170680, ¶ 31, 98 N.E.3d 459, 468. In order to claim an interest in the condemnation award itself, the attorney must have a secured position by virtue of an express contractual agreement to that effect with the owner.
Village of Clarendon Hills v. Mulder, 278 Ill. App. 3d 727, 735–736, 663 N.E.2d 435, 442 (2d Dist. 1996). A personal contingent fee agreement does not itself grant an attorney an equitable lien against the fund the client might draw upon to pay attorney’s fees. To assert an equitable lien, the attorney must establish that the client has assigned a portion of the award to the attorney.
Department of Pub. Works v. Exchange Nat’l Bank, 93 Ill. App. 3d 390, 394, 417 N.E.2d 1045, 1048 (2d Dist. 1981).

Even where the attorney has received an equitable lien in the award, the attorney’s claim falls behind those of other claimants with priority. Thus, a prior mortgage will prime an attorney’s lien.
Village of Clarendon Hills v. Mulder, 278 Ill. App. 3d 727, 735–736, 663 N.E.2d 435, 442 (2d Dist. 1996).

The common fund doctrine is used in other contexts by attorneys to assert a claim against an award obtained for the benefit of parties with whom the attorney does not have an attorney-client relationship. The common fund doctrine does not apply to condemnation awards.
Village of Clarendon Hills v. Mulder, 278 Ill. App. 3d 727, 733, 663 N.E.2d 435, 441 (2d Dist. 1996).

Contingent fee agreements are common in eminent domain cases, and are generally enforced. Even where there is no enforcible agreement, attorney’s fees may nevertheless be obtained. Neither owner nor attorney usually contemplates that legal services are to be rendered gratuitously. Thus, courts have found an implied contract or an owner’s obligation to pay attorney’s fees on a quantum meruit basis.
Glenview Park Dist. v. Redemptorist Fathers of Glenview, 89 Ill. App. 3d 623, 627, 412 N.E.2d 162, 165 (1st Dist. 1980); Department of Pub. Works v. Lanter, 15 Ill. 2d 33, 153 N.E.2d 552, 555 (1958); Forest Preserve Dist. of Cook County v. Continental Community Bank and Trust Co., 2017 IL App (1st) 170680, ¶ 49, 98 N.E.3d 459, 472; see also Chicago & S. Traction Co. v. Flaherty, 222 Ill. 67, 68–69, 78 N.E. 29 (1906). Under the theory of quantum meruit, the trial court is to award as much as the attorney deserves, using the broad discretion afforded it due to the advantage of close observation of the attorney’s work and the trial judge’s deep understanding of the skill and time required in the case.
Forest Preserve Dist. of Cook County v. Continental Community Bank and Trust Co., 2017 IL App (1st) 170680, ¶ 50, 98 N.E.3d 459, 473. In making its determination, the court should assess all relevant factors, including the time and labor required, the attorney’s skill and standing, the nature of the cause, the novelty and difficulty of the subject matter, the attorney’s degree of responsibility in managing the case, the usual and customary charge for that type of work in the community, and the benefits resulting to the client.
Forest Preserve Dist. of Cook County v. Continental Community Bank and Trust Co., 2017 IL App (1st) 170680, ¶ 50, 98 N.E.3d 459, 473.

Whether the court has authority to grant attorney’s fees is a question of law, to be reviewed de novo, while the court’s decision as to whether to award authorized fees is reviewed for an abuse of discretion.
Forest Preserve Dist. of Cook County v. Continental Community Bank and Trust Co., 2017 IL App (1st) 170680, ¶ 32, 98 N.E.3d 459, 468.
